text: is there a Julia nbdev equiv?

elements.text: is there a Julia nbdev equiv?

text: If/when VS Code integration happens, it'll be better than nbdev IMO

elements.text: If/when VS Code integration happens, it'll be better than nbdev IMO

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/chrlaf|@chrlaf>: <https://twitter.com/AriKatz20|@AriKatz20> <https://twitter.com/cmmmsubmm|@cmmmsubmm> ... switch just yet with too many unknowns. I built a prototype with #nbdev, #fastai v2, and we leverage lots of SOTA pytorch code. AFAIK there aren't direct equivalents for these yet for Julia. (Pluto.jl is awesome but not quite what we need)

text: I believe it, someone would need to add libraries for more robust docs generation and inline test reporting to Pluto

elements.text: I believe it, someone would need to add libraries for more robust docs generation and inline test reporting to Pluto

text: That said, I personally think all the advantages of nbdev are not enough to compensate for being forced to develop in Jupyter...hence why Pluto - VS Code integration is so promising

elements.text: That said, I personally think all the advantages of nbdev are not enough to compensate for being forced to develop in Jupyter...hence why Pluto - VS Code integration is so promising

text: I'll refrain from expressing my opinion on whehter (Python) fastai is a good poster child for nbdev because that's not relevant to this discussion :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I'll refrain from expressing my opinion on whehter (Python) fastai is a good poster child for nbdev because that's not relevant to this discussion

text: I have a working prototype of a document generation system running here: <https://github.com/lorenzoh/Pollen.jl>. It's based on tree rewriting and built for interactive work with event-based incremental updates. There's no documentation yet but it's used to generate the current FastAI.jl docs here: <https://fluxml.ai/FastAI.jl/dev/README.md.html>. Currently I'm using it to generate documentation but it'll be easy to add support for outputting .jl files from literate source files like notebooks, and I plan to do so in the future.
